justification: "Participants completed a Conditional Associative Learning paradigm, adapted to investigate the contributions of RL and WM in learning" indicates the paradigm is the instrument used to index RL processes.

measured_by: Set-size manipulation (3 vs. 6 stimuli) within the RLWM task
justification: The text states that blocks with 6 stimuli "resulted in greater WM load" and that the set-size effect "supports the involvement of WM in learning," showing that the set-size factor is the operational measure of WM contribution.

"In the distractor task, participants completed 5 blocks of a N-back task. This task was designed to tax the WM system, clearing any working memory information…"—the N-back is explicitly used as the WM taxing/measurement tool.
The authors note that the Test Phase "probed how well stimulus-response pairs were learned by a RL process alone, presumably without the aid of WM," making this phase a measure of RL-based retention.
The study "manipulated stimulus discriminability" using "three stimulus conditions"—Standard, Text, and Variants—so these condition sets function as the operational measure of discriminability.
